awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Developing a Normative Framework for Cyber Warfare
awd_abstract_narration:
Project Overview 
 
The PIs propose to develop a normative framework for policies of cyber warfare. They plan to conduct an investigation into cyber warfare practices and to evaluate the extent to which current cyber warfare conforms to basic war ethics principles underlying the Hague and Geneva conventions including discrimination, attribution, proportionality, and deception. For these purposes, they are partnering with the Consortium for Emerging Technologies, Military Operations, and National Security (CETMONS).
 
Intellectual Merit 
 
The US is clearly worried about cyber attacks; other nations could inflict serious damage to military capabilities, as well as strike physical targets and infrastructure, with more anonymity and without placing their soldiers at risk. In response to these prospects, the US is developing a thoughtful plan to operate with greater safety and security in cyberspace. However, cyber warfare also poses great challenges to just war theory, the basis for international laws of armed conflict. This project fills an important need by investigating tensions with the basic principles of war, helping to determine the permissibility and policies of cyber warfare. It will provide a concise set of normative principles that could also serve to safeguard cyberspace, which is increasingly essential to modern life. 
 
Broader Impact 
 
The results of this project will include a comprehensive report on cyber warfare ethics, a university-level ethics course, and an edited volume that would serve as a text for such a course. This report will identify specific options for a coherent cyber war ethics in clear language useful for policymakers. The PIs plan to solicit input and disseminate their research through public workshops, one at the beginning and another at the end of the project, as well as conference and classroom talks throughout.

por.por_cntn:
Philosophical and ethical discussions of warfare are often tied to emerging technologies and techniques. In particular, discussions over how warfare can be conducted in a morally justified manner have come in response to such changes in the character of warfare. Whether it is the development of weapons that can kill at an ever greater distance or shifts in the kinds and magnitude of weapons, scholars have attempted to understand and assess whether such novel technologies and techniques should, in fact, be used and what implications their rise portends for the ethics of war. Today we are presented with what many believe is a radical shift in the nature of war – the realization of conflict in the cyber-realm, the so-called ‘fifth domain’ of warfare. Does an aggressive act in the cyber-realm constitute an act of war? If so, what rules should govern such warfare? Are the standard theories of just war capable of analyzing and assessing this mode of conflict?

This new form of war – cyberwarfare – has been brought about by a series of technological and social shifts. Most obvious has been the unprecedented development of information and communication technologies (ICTs). Clearly, many important activities conducted by individuals, private companies, and state actors now occur in the cyber-realm, supported by the internet. Furthermore, as the character of military engagement shifts to be more dependent upon ICTs, militaries themselves create new targets for potential cyber-attacks. The scenario of a military drone armed with lethal weapons being ‘hacked’ presents one such extreme example of how ICT reliance creates novel vulnerabilities. We must also recognize that a great deal of critical infrastructure, while reliant upon ICTs, does not necessarily connect to the internet. Supervisory Control And Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems, for example, are used as mechanisms to control energy, water, and manufacturing industries. Many of these SCADA systems are not directly connected to the internet. However, as the Stuxnet virus has shown, such ‘air-gaps’ between critical infrastructure and the internet do not present sufficient protection against cyber-attacks. The base claim, however, remains the same – with the increasing reliance upon ICTs in the modern world comes the potential for new and potentially crippling vulnerabilities.

A key point to recognize is that cyberwarfare is likely going to be more than a piece of code used to bring down a piece of critical infrastructure. Cyber-sabotage, such as the interference with radar systems to enable more effective air-strikes, is one way cyberwarfare could be waged. Cyber-espionage, such as state actors hacking private and governmental communications that were presumed secure, is well worth normative consideration for the ways in which it acts as a potential game-changer in the international intelligence world. Cyber-surveillance, such as national security agencies monitoring the content of internet based-communications in pursuit of terrorists – an activity recently garnering high-profile attention in the United States – is another way in which cyber capabilities and exploitation call for ethical scrutiny. All of these activities present ways in which the cyber-realm is rapidly becoming part of the 5th domain, a new space in which warfare or warfare-like activities are conducted.

Upon short reflection, these changing circumstances present us with a series of questions demanding serious attention. Is there such a thing as cyberwarfare? How do the existing rules of engagement and theories from the just war tradition apply to cyberwarfare? How should we assess a cyber-attack conducted by a state agency against private enterprise and vice versa? Furthermore, how should actors behave in the cyber-realm? Are there ethical norms that can be applied to the cyber-realm? Are the classic just war constraints of non-combatant immunity and proportionality possible in this realm? Especially given the idea that events that are constrained within the cyber-realm do not directly physically harm anyone, what do traditional ethics of war conventions say about this new space?

Our research project sought to address these, and other, questions.  We leveraged a strong team of international researchers, publishing in top journals and with top presses.  Woth specific note is the first-ever book on this topc, *Binary Bullets:  The Ethics of Cyberwarfare* (Oxford University Press).  We also collaborated with a range of institutions, ranging from the International Committee for the Red Cross to the Naval Postgraduate School to the US Naval Academy.  We also had substantial outreach with Euroean partners, mostly facilitated and hosted by the Faculty of Political Science at the University of Iceland.  We appreciate the opportunity to do this work, sponsored by the National Science Foundation, and to advance conversatons relating to ethical, legal, and policy issues that adhere to cyberwarfare.
